channel.title: Comments on: Signing Your Social Security Card

item.title: By: Mike M
item.dc:creator: Mike M
item.description: What if your son is 29 years old, is disabled and I am his appointed legal guardian. He does/can’t sign documents. Do I sign SS card on his behalf?
item.content:encoded: What if your son is 29 years old, is disabled and I am his appointed legal guardian. He does/can’t sign documents. Do I sign SS card on his behalf?

item.title: By: Chris Odum
item.dc:creator: Chris Odum
item.description: Your child doesn't need an SSN to get medical insurance coverage. Neither of our children has an SSN and insurance works just fine. There is no requirement for a US Citizen to have an SSN.
item.content:encoded: Your child doesn’t need an SSN to get medical insurance coverage. Neither of our children has an SSN and insurance works just fine. There is no requirement for a US Citizen to have an SSN.

item.title: By: Jess
item.dc:creator: Jess
item.description: Is it okay to have a picture of your social security card if the card is lost or stolen? I am going to go test for my knowledge test and idk if it’ll be fine to use the picture of my full SSN instead. I don’t have the original card.
item.content:encoded: Is it okay to have a picture of your social security card if the card is lost or stolen? I am going to go test for my knowledge test and idk if it’ll be fine to use the picture of my full SSN instead. I don’t have the original card.

item.title: By: cja
item.dc:creator: cja
item.description: Does the middle name need to be written on a social security card if it comes printed on the card.
item.content:encoded: Does the middle name need to be written on a social security card if it comes printed on the card.

item.title: By: P Denise
item.dc:creator: P Denise
item.description: My signature is different than how it appears on my card. Do I have to sign it the way it appears on the card or can I sign it the way I sign everything else? Thank you for your time.
item.content:encoded: My signature is different than how it appears on my card. Do I have to sign it the way it appears on the card or can I sign it the way I sign everything else? Thank you for your time.

item.title: By: Char
item.dc:creator: Char
item.description: Thanks for the help. I guess I'll request a replacement and then have her sign it when she starts work. In response to Hank's comment, I got our daughter a delayed birth certificate after her dad passed away , as I needed to apply for benefits for her. It is a huge ordeal. Took about 5 months. Getting a ss# when you haven't had one takes about 3 months.
item.content:encoded: Thanks for the help. I guess I’ll request a replacement and then have her sign it when she starts work. In response to Hank’s comment, I got our daughter a delayed birth certificate after her dad passed away , as I needed to apply for benefits for her. It is a huge ordeal. Took about 5 months. Getting a ss# when you haven’t had one takes about 3 months.

item.title: By: Deb
item.dc:creator: Deb
item.description: Children eligible for the Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend need the social security card to apply for the dividend and to file the subsequent federal tax return on the income.
item.content:encoded: Children eligible for the Alaska Permanent Fund Dividend need the social security card to apply for the dividend and to file the subsequent federal tax return on the income.

item.title: By: Alex
item.dc:creator: Alex
item.description: Related question: I signed my SS card at like 16 or so--before I had a set signature. Since then I developed an actual one and it's nothing like the one on my SS card. Anyone know if this would be an issue? Will this be an issue for jobs if the signature on my card doesnt match the signature that I sign paperwork with? If so, should I get a new one and then use my "real"/current signature?
item.content:encoded: Related question: I signed my SS card at like 16 or so–before I had a set signature. Since then I developed an actual one and it’s nothing like the one on my SS card. Anyone know if this would be an issue? Will this be an issue for jobs if the signature on my card doesnt match the signature that I sign paperwork with? If so, should I get a new one and then use my “real”/current signature?

item.title: By: Alex
item.dc:creator: Alex
item.description: Sean, just in case there's a misunderstanding, there are actually several reasons for a child to get a SS card. You do not need a SS card as a child, but considering the benefits, there is little to no reason to not get it right away--as a baby. As for the signature question: Parents do not sign for their child; and it doesn't need to be signed by the child until they are 18 or they gets a job first. All of this has already been stated a few times by the others lol. Thanks Amy, Erica, and Earthgal.
item.content:encoded: Sean, just in case there’s a misunderstanding, there are actually several reasons for a child to get a SS card. You do not need a SS card as a child, but considering the benefits, there is little to no reason to not get it right away–as a baby. As for the signature question: Parents do not sign for their child; and it doesn’t need to be signed by the child until they are 18 or they gets a job first. All of this has already been stated a few times by the others lol. Thanks Amy, Erica, and Earthgal.

item.title: By: Erica
item.dc:creator: Erica
item.description: Ok so I got on the social security website and consulted a professor since I am a social work student and the child does not need a social security card at birth but the way the government has it it's almost like you need one. For a child it is needed because you need the number to claim them as a dependent on an income tax return, to buy savings bonds for the child, to get medical coverage for the child and to apply for government services for the child. If you wait to get it once the child leaves the hospital after birth the process is longer and drawn out because the birth certificate needs to be varified and there are many other reasons why it is drawn out.
item.content:encoded: Ok so I got on the social security website and consulted a professor since I am a social work student and the child does not need a social security card at birth but the way the government has it it’s almost like you need one. For a child it is needed because you need the number to claim them as a dependent on an income tax return, to buy savings bonds for the child, to get medical coverage for the child and to apply for government services for the child. If you wait to get it once the child leaves the hospital after birth the process is longer and drawn out because the birth certificate needs to be varified and there are many other reasons why it is drawn out.
